data.description: 꿀 means honey, and 잼 is a reduced form of 재미, which means fun or interesting.
data.exampleSentence:
이거 완전 꿀잼
(This is so much fun!)

data.description: The opposite of 꿀잼. 노 is the english word no, and 잼 here also means fun or interesting. Often used after someone makes a bad joke.
data.exampleSentence:
아 진짜 노잼
(That wasn't funny)

data.description: 모쏠 is short for 모태 솔로. 모태 means from birth, and 솔로 is the english word for solo.
data.exampleSentence:
너 모태솔로야?
(Have you been single your whole life?)

data.description: 심 means heart, and 쿵 represents the sound of your heard beating. It is used positively to mean that something has attracted you or something that is cute.
data.exampleSentence:
나 저 강아지 보고 심쿵했어
(That dog is so cute!)

data.description: 대박 is a common term used when something cool, fun or good happens. It is also used as an intensifier
data.exampleSentence:
이번 공연 완전 대박이야
(This concert was super cool!)

data.description: 현웃 is short for 현실 웃음. 현실 means reality, and 웃음 means laughter. Commonly used in texts to show that you actually laughed out loud.
data.exampleSentence:
나 현웃터졌어
(I actually laughed out loud)

data.description: 멘붕 is short for 멘탈 붕괴. 멘탈 is the english word mental, and 붕괴 means collapsed. Commonly used when something bad happened and you don't know what to do
data.exampleSentence:
나 거의 멘붕이야
(I almost had a mental breakdown)

data.description: 돌 means rock, and 직구 means fastball(baseball). Commonly used to describe words or actions that are very direct
data.exampleSentence:
돌직구 날리지 마
(Don't be too direct)

data.description: 간지 is a Jeju dialect for 횃대 (coat hanger). Commonly used to describe people with good sense of style
data.exampleSentence:
너 가방 좀 간지난다
(Your bag looks really cool)

data.description: 강추 is short for 강한(strong) 추천(recommendation). Used when you want to recommend product or activities to others.
data.exampleSentence:
이 회사 제품은 진짜 강추
(I really recommend this company's products)

data.description: 고딩 is short for 고등학생(high school student). -딩 can be used with elementary school students(초딩), middle school students(중딩), etc.
data.exampleSentence:
나는 고딩일 때가 제일 힘들었어
(High school was the hardest time for me)

data.description: 깬다 literally means to break. Commonly used to mean breaking a good image.
data.exampleSentence:
저 남자 자꾸 방귀뀌니까 확 깬다
(His image was ruined because he kept farting)

data.description: 노가다 comes from the japanes word for labor. Commonly used to refer to work or activities that require a lot of manual labor
data.exampleSentence:
여름방학에 노가다만 뛰었어
(All I did this summer was manual labor)

data.description: 돌싱 is short for 돌아온 (back to) 싱글 (single). Used to refer to people who has divorced and is single now.
data.exampleSentence:
돌싱들만을 위한 어플이 있어
(There's an app only for divorced singles)

data.description: 바가지를 쓰다 literally means to wear 바가지 (bowl) on your head.  However it is only used to mean to be ripped off.
data.exampleSentence:
나 옷가게에서 바가지 썼어
(I was ripped off at the clothing store)

data.description: 뽀록 comes from the japanese word for fluke. Commonly used when someone with low skill shows good performance.
data.exampleSentence:
뽀록이네
(That was a fluke)

data.description: 쌍수 is short for 쌍꺼풀(double eyelid) 수술(surgery). Used to refer to the surgery to get double eyelids.
data.exampleSentence:
나 어제 쌍수했어
(I did my double eyelid surgery yesterday)

data.description: 쌩얼 is short for 생(bare) 얼굴(face). Used to refer to face without any makeup.
data.exampleSentence:
나 오늘 쌩얼이야
(I didn't wear any makeup today)

data.description: 썰렁하다 literally means chilly. Used when someone spoils the mood with a lame joke.
data.exampleSentence:
너의 개그는 썰렁해
(Your joke is lame)

data.definition: romantic relationship but not quite dating yet
data.description: 썸 is comes from the english word for something. Used to refer to a relationship between two people who aren't quite dating but are romantically closer than most people.
data.exampleSentence:
우리 썸타는 중이야
(We have something going on between us)

data.description: 잉여 literally means leftover. However, it is used to refer to a person with no money, no house, no job, etc.
data.exampleSentence:
나는 오늘 잉여롭게 집에서 쉬었어
(I was a couch potato today)

data.description: 지못미 is short for 지키주지 못해서 미안해 (sorry for not saving you). Used to express that you feel sorry for what happened to someone else.
data.exampleSentence:
지못미
(I'm sorry for what happened)

data.description: 쪽팔리다 is commonly used when you are embarrassed. Not as polite as the synonyms 창피하다 or 부끄럽다.
data.exampleSentence:
바지를 안입고 밖에 나가서 쪽팔렸어
(I was ashamed because I went outside with no pants on)
